dipoleDirectionDescription.value: The convention used to show direction of dipoles.

surfaceColorDescription.value: Color gradient used to represent positive and negative electrostatic potential.

underDevelopment.line1.value: Real Molecules is not currently available in HTML5.

underDevelopment.line2.value: If your device runs Java, you can use the Java version at

twoAtoms.value: Experiment with electronegativity values to explore bond polarity and character.

threeAtoms.value: Explore how bond dipole size and orientation influence molecular polarity.

realMolecules.value: Explore real molecules in three dimensions.

dipoleDirectionChange.value: Bond dipole { $bond } arrow now points to Atom { $atom }.

accessibleHelpText.value: Explore with or without bond dipole shown.

accessibleHelpTextPlural.value: Explore with or without bond dipoles shown.

accessibleHelpText.value: Explore with or without partial charges shown.
Explore with or without bond character shown.
Explore with or without molecular dipole shown.
Show or hide labels for each atom in the molecule.
Explore with or without atom electronegativities shown.
Explore with different charge surfaces shown.

electrostaticPotentialHelpText.value:
{ $colorMap ->
  [blueWhiteRed] Electrostatic potential ranges from positive to neutral to negative (surface colors: blue to white to red).
  *[rainbow] Electrostatic potential ranges from positive to neutral to negative (surface colors: rainbow, blue to red).
}

electronDensityHelpText.value: Electron density ranges from less to more (surface colors: white to dark grey).

accessibleHelpText.value: Turns the electric field on or off. When on, a negative plate appears on left and a positive plate on right, creating the electric field.

rotateOrMoveInSmallerSteps.value: Rotate or move in smaller steps

accessibleHelpText.value: Change how strongly an atom attracts electrons.

bondCharacter.value:
{ $bondCharacter ->
  [nonpolarCovalent] nonpolar covalent
  [nearlyNonpolarCovalent] nearly nonpolar covalent
  [slightlyPolarCovalent] slightly polar covalent
  [polarCovalent] polar covalent
  [slightlyIonic] slightly ionic
  *[mostlyIonic] mostly ionic
}

electronDensity.value:
{ $density ->
  [evenlyShared] evenly
  [nearlyEvenlyShared] nearly evenly
  [slightlyUnevenlyShared] slightly unevenly
  [unevenlyShared] unevenly
  [veryUnevenlyShared] very unevenly
  *[mostUnevenlyShared] most unevenly
}

electronDensityShift.value:
{ $shift ->
  [shiftedSlightly] shifted slightly
  [shifted] shifted
  [shiftedMuchMore] shifted much more
  *[shiftedAlmostCompletely] shifted almost completely
}

electrostaticPotentialUppercase.value:
{ $potential ->
  [no] No
  [verySmall] Very small
  [small] Small
  [medium] Medium
  [fairlyLarge] Fairly large
  *[large] Large
}

electrostaticPotentialProgress.value:
{ $progress ->
  [morePositive] more positive
  [lessPositive] less positive
  [neutral] neutral
  [lessNegative] less negative
  *[moreNegative] more negative
}

electrostaticRegions.value:
{ $regions ->
  [verySlightly] Very slightly
  [slightly] Slightly
  [moderately] Moderately
  [highly] Highly
  *[veryHighly] Very highly
}

electronegativity.value:
{ $level ->
  [veryLow] very low
  [low] low
  [mediumLow] medium-low
  [mediumHigh] medium-high
  [high] high
  *[veryHigh] very high
}

molecularDipole.value:
{ $magnitude ->
  [no] no
  [verySmall] very small
  [small] small
  [medium] medium
  [fairlyLarge] fairly large
  [large] large
  [veryLarge] very large
  *[extremelyLarge] extremely large
}

polarity.value:
{ $polarity ->
  [nonpolar] nonpolar
  [veryWeaklyPolar] very weakly polar
  [weaklyPolar] weakly polar
  [polar] polar
  [stronglyPolar] strongly polar
  *[veryStronglyPolar] very strongly polar
}

partialChargeMagnitude.value:
{ $magnitude ->
  [zero] zero
  [verySmall] very small
  [small] small
  [medium] medium
  [fairlyLarge] fairly large
  [large] large
  [veryLarge] very large
  *[extremelyLarge] extremely large
}

bondDipole.value:
{ $magnitude ->
  [no] no
  [verySmall] very small
  [small] small
  [medium] medium
  [fairlyLarge] fairly large
  *[large] large
}

molecularPolarity.value:
{ $polarity ->
  [nonpolar] nonpolar
  [weaklyPolar] weakly polar
  [polar] polar
  [moderatelyPolar] moderately polar
  [stronglyPolar] strongly polar
  *[veryStronglyPolar] very strongly polar
}

shape.value:
{ $shape ->
  [linear] linear
  [nearlyLinear] nearly linear
  [slightlyBent] slightly bent
  [bent] bent
  [veryBent] very bent
  [extremelyBentSlightOverlap] extremely bent, atoms overlap
  *[atomsOverlap] linear, atoms completely overlap
}

shapeGeometry.value:
{ $geometry ->
  [linear] linear
  [bent] bent
  [trigonalPlanar] trigonal planar
  [trigonalPyramidal] trigonal pyramidal
  *[tetrahedral] tetrahedral
}

playArea.value: There is an interactive two-atom molecule, A–B. You can rotate the molecule, and change each atom's electronegativity to explore the effect on the bond dipole. Turn on an electric field to see how the molecule responds.

controlArea.value: Checkboxes change visibility of the bond dipole and partial charges. A radio button lets you choose to add electrostatic potential or electron density surfaces to the molecule. You can turn on the electric field, or reset the sim to start over.

currentDetails.value: Currently, the molecule is { $polarity }. The electric field is { $field }.

interactionHint.value: Change atom electronegativities to explore the effect on the bond dipole.

partialChargesDetail.value: { a11y_twoAtomsScreen_moleculeAB_partialChargesDescription } Atom A has partial { $chargeA } charge, Atom B has partial { $chargeB } charge.

electrostaticPotentialRegions.value: { a11y_twoAtomsScreen_moleculeAB_electrostaticPotentialDescription } { $regionA } { $chargeA } towards Atom A. { $regionB } { $chargeB } towards Atom B.

firstTwoRegions.value: Electron density is { $density } distributed between atoms.

lastFourRegions.value: Electron density is { $density } distributed, { $electronDensityShift } towards Atom { $atom }.

orientationDescription.value: Molecule is { $orientation } with Atom A { $atomAPosition } o'clock and Atom B { $atomBPosition } o'clock.

playArea.value: There is an interactive three-atom molecule, A–B–C. You can change each atom's electronegativity, rotate the molecule around the central atom B, and move atoms A and C to adjust the bond angle. As you make changes, you can explore how shape and bond polarity affect the molecule's overall dipole.

controlArea.value: Checkboxes change visibility of bond dipoles, molecular dipole, and partial charges. You can turn on the electric field to see how the molecule responds, or reset the sim to start over.

currentDetails.value: Currently, the molecule is { $polarity }, the shape is { $shape }. The electric field is { $field }.

interactionHint.value: Move Atom A or C to explore how shape changes the molecular dipole.

orientationDescription.value: Molecule is { $shape } with Atom A { $atomAPosition } o'clock, Atom B at center, and Atom C { $atomCPosition } o'clock.

electronegativityValues.value: Electronegativity for Atom A is { $enA }, for Atom B is { $enB }, for Atom C is { $enC }.

molecularDipoleTwice.value: Molecular dipole is twice the size of bond dipoles.

bondDipoleABDescription.value: { a11y_threeAtomsScreen_moleculeABC_bondDipoleAB } AB bond dipole points to Atom { $atom }, { $direction } o'clock.

bondDipoleBCDescription.value: { a11y_threeAtomsScreen_moleculeABC_bondDipoleBC } BC bond dipole points to Atom { $atom }, { $direction } o'clock.

partialChargesDescription.value:
{ $sign ->
  [positive] Atom { $atom } has { $magnitude } positive partial charge.
  [negative] Atom { $atom } has { $magnitude } negative partial charge.
  *[zero] Atom { $atom } has { $magnitude } partial charge.
}

accessibleHelpText.value: Move Atom A around center Atom B.
Move Atom C around center Atom B.

playArea.value: There is an interactive molecule from a list of real molecules. You can rotate it in 3D and explore its atoms, shape, and polarity.

controlArea.value: You can use checkboxes to show or hide bond dipoles, the molecular dipole, and atom details. You can also choose between electrostatic potential or electron density surfaces to see how charge is distributed. View molecules using the basic or advanced model. Reset the sim to start over.

currentDetails.value: Currently, you are viewing { $moleculeName }, with { $shapeGeometry } geometry.

interactionHint.value: Choose a molecule and rotate it to explore how shape and bond polarity determine the molecular dipole.

accessibleHelpText.value: Move molecule in three dimensions. Use keyboard shortcuts to rotate molecule around vertical and horizontal axes.

objectResponses.value:
{ $direction ->
  [up] rotating up, around horizontal axis
  [down] rotating down, around horizontal axis
  [left] rotating left, around vertical axis
  *[right] rotating right, around vertical axis
}

electronegativitiesTable.value: Atom electronegativities are: hydrogen 2.2, boron 2.0, carbon 2.6, nitrogen 3.0, oxygen 3.4, fluorine 4.0, and chlorine 3.2.

accessibleHelpText.value: Choose a different molecule to view.

basicHelpText.value: Explore bond dipoles based on electronegativity differences.

advancedHelpText.value: Explore bond dipoles based on partial charges.

description.value:
{ $molecule ->
  [hydrogen] The molecule upper H2 has linear geometry and is nonpolar, with the hydrogen atoms single-bonded.
  [nitrogen] The molecule upper N2 has linear geometry and is nonpolar, with the nitrogen atoms triple-bonded.
  [oxygen] The molecule upper O2 has linear geometry and is nonpolar, with the oxygen atoms double-bonded.
  [fluorine] The molecule upper F2 has linear geometry and is nonpolar, with the fluorine atoms single-bonded.
  [hydrogenFluoride] The molecule upper H upper F has linear geometry and is very strongly polar, with the hydrogen single-bonded to fluorine.
  [water] The molecule upper H2 upper O has bent geometry and is very strongly polar, with the central atom oxygen single-bonded to each hydrogen.
  [carbonDioxide] The molecule upper C upper O2 has linear geometry and is nonpolar, with the central atom carbon double-bonded to each oxygen.
  [hydrogenCyanide] The molecule upper H upper C upper N has linear geometry and is polar, with the central atom carbon single-bonded to hydrogen and triple-bonded to nitrogen.
  [ozone] The molecule O3 has bent geometry and is nonpolar, with 1.5 bonds between oxygen atoms.
  [ammonia] The molecule upper N upper H3 has trigonal pyramidal geometry and is strongly polar, with the central atom nitrogen single-bonded to each hydrogen.
  [borane] The molecule upper B upper H3 has trigonal planar geometry and is nonpolar, with the central atom boron single-bonded to each hydrogen.
  [boronTrifluoride] The molecule upper B upper F3 has trigonal planar geometry and is nonpolar, with the central atom boron single-bonded to each fluorine.
  [formaldehyde] The molecule upper C upper H2 upper O has trigonal planar geometry and is strongly polar, with the central atom carbon single-bonded to each hydrogen and double-bonded to oxygen.
  [methane] The molecule upper C upper H4 has tetrahedral geometry and is nonpolar, with the central atom carbon single-bonded to each hydrogen.
  [fluoromethane] The molecule upper C upper H3 upper F has tetrahedral geometry and is strongly polar, with the central atom carbon single-bonded to each hydrogen and fluorine.
  [difluoromethane] The molecule upper C upper H2 upper F2 has tetrahedral geometry and is very strongly polar, with the central atom carbon single-bonded to each hydrogen and fluorine.
  [trifluoromethane] The molecule upper C upper H upper F3 has tetrahedral geometry and is very strongly polar, with the central atom carbon single-bonded to hydrogen and each fluorine.
  [tetrafluoromethane] The molecule upper C upper F4 has tetrahedral geometry and is nonpolar, with the central atom carbon single-bonded to each fluorine.
  *[chloroform] The molecule upper C upper H upper Cl3 has tetrahedral geometry and is polar, with the central atom carbon single-bonded to hydrogen and each chlorine.
}

bondDipole.value:
{ $molecule ->
  [hydrogen] No bond dipole.
  [nitrogen] No bond dipole.
  [oxygen] No bond dipole.
  [fluorine] No bond dipole.
  [hydrogenFluoride] Large bond dipole, pointing towards fluorine.
  [water] Fairly large bond dipoles, pointing towards oxygen.
  [carbonDioxide] Medium bond dipoles, pointing towards oxygens.
  [hydrogenCyanide] Very small carbon hydrogen bond dipole, pointing towards carbon. Small carbon nitrogen bond dipole, pointing towards nitrogen.
  [ozone] No bond dipoles.
  [ammonia] Medium bond dipoles, pointing towards nitrogen.
  [borane] Tiny bond dipoles, pointing towards hydrogens.
  [boronTrifluoride] Large bond dipoles, pointing towards fluorines.
  [formaldehyde] Very small carbon hydrogen bond dipoles, pointing towards carbon. Medium carbon oxygen bond dipole, pointing towards oxygen.
  [methane] Very small bond dipoles, pointing towards carbon.
  [fluoromethane] Very small carbon hydrogen bond dipoles, pointing towards carbon. Large carbon fluorine bond dipole, pointing towards fluorine.
  [difluoromethane] Very small carbon hydrogen bond dipoles, pointing towards carbon. Fairly large carbon fluorine bond dipoles, pointing towards fluorines.
  [trifluoromethane] Very small carbon hydrogen bond dipoles, pointing towards carbon. Fairly large carbon fluorine bond dipoles, pointing towards fluorines.
  [tetrafluoromethane] Fairly large carbon fluorine bond dipoles, pointing towards fluorines.
  *[chloroform] Very small carbon hydrogen bond dipole, pointing towards carbon. Small carbon chlorine bond dipoles, pointing towards chlorines.
}

electronDensity.value:
{ $molecule ->
  [hydrogen] Electron density is evenly shared between atoms.
  [nitrogen] Electron density is evenly shared between atoms.
  [oxygen] Electron density is evenly shared between atoms.
  [fluorine] Electron density is evenly shared between atoms.
  [hydrogenFluoride] Electron density is very unevenly shared, shifted towards fluorine.
  [water] Electron density is very unevenly shared, shifted towards oxygen.
  [carbonDioxide] Electron density is unevenly shared, but symmetrically arranged.
  [hydrogenCyanide] Electron density is very unevenly shared, shifted towards nitrogen.
  [ozone] Electron density is slightly unevenly shared, shifted towards terminal oxygens.
  [ammonia] Electron density is very unevenly shared, shifted towards nitrogen.
  [borane] Electron density is evenly shared between atoms.
  [boronTrifluoride] Electron density is unevenly shared, but symmetrically arranged.
  [formaldehyde] Electron density is very unevenly shared, shifted towards oxygen.
  [methane] Electron density is unevenly shared, but symmetrically arranged.
  [fluoromethane] Electron density is very unevenly shared, shifted towards fluorine.
  [difluoromethane] Electron density is very unevenly shared, shifted towards fluorines.
  [trifluoromethane] Electron density is very unevenly shared, shifted towards fluorines.
  [tetrafluoromethane] Electron density is unevenly shared, but symmetrically arranged.
  *[chloroform] Electron density is unevenly shared, shifted towards chlorines.
}

bondDipole.value:
{ $molecule ->
  [hydrogen] No bond dipole.
  [nitrogen] No bond dipole.
  [oxygen] No bond dipole.
  [fluorine] No bond dipole.
  [hydrogenFluoride] Large bond dipole, pointing towards fluorine.
  [water] Fairly large bond dipoles, pointing towards oxygen.
  [carbonDioxide] Small bond dipoles, pointing towards oxygens.
  [hydrogenCyanide] Small carbon hydrogen bond dipole, pointing towards carbon. Large carbon nitrogen bond dipole, pointing towards nitrogen.
  [ozone] Small bond dipoles, pointing towards terminal oxygens.
  [ammonia] Fairly large bond dipoles, pointing towards nitrogen.
  [borane] Fairly large bond dipoles, pointing towards hydrogens.
  [boronTrifluoride] Small bond dipoles, pointing towards fluorines.

}

partialCharges.value:
{ $molecule ->
  [hydrogen] No partial charges.
  [nitrogen] No partial charges.
  [oxygen] No partial charges.
  [fluorine] No partial charges.
  [hydrogenFluoride] Partial charge for hydrogen is +0.22, for fluorine is -0.22.
  [water] Partial charge for hydrogen is +0.15, for oxygen is -0.30.
  [carbonDioxide] Partial charge for carbon is +0.33, for oxygen is -0.17.
  [hydrogenCyanide] Partial charge for hydrogen is +0.13, for carbon is +0.06, and for nitrogen is -0.19.
  [ozone] Partial charge for central oxygen is +0.19, for each terminal oxygen is -0.10.
  [ammonia] Partial charge for hydrogen is +0.9, for nitrogen is -0.27.
  [borane] Partial charge for boron is +0.17, for hydrogen is -0.06.
  [boronTrifluoride] Partial charge for boron is +0.41, for fluorine is -0.14
  [formaldehyde] Partial charge for hydrogen is +0.04, for carbon is +0.14, for oxygen is -0.22.
  [methane] Partial charge for hydrogen is +0.03, for carbon is -0.12.
  [fluoromethane] Partial charge for hydrogen is +0.04, for carbon is +0.04, for fluorine is -0.17.
  [difluoromethane] Partial charge for hydrogen is +0.05, for carbon is +0.17, for fluorine is -0.14.
  [trifluoromethane] Partial charge for hydrogen is +0.07, for carbon is +0.27, for fluorine is -0.11.
  [tetrafluoromethane] Partial charge for carbon is +0.37, for fluorine is -0.09.
  *[chloroform] Partial charge for hydrogen is +0.07, for carbon is +0.13, for chlorine is -0.06.
}
